How does the bispecific fusion construct: By combining Sb#15 and Sb#68 to enhance binding affinity through avidity effects.
By targeting only the ACE2 binding site to increase specificity.
By binding to a single epitope to prevent viral escape.
By reducing the size of the sybodies for better tissue penetration.
What is the advantage of the trimeric co: It achieves low picomolar IC50 values against various SARS-CoV-2 variants.
It targets only the Alpha variant with high specificity.
It binds to the spike protein with low affinity to reduce side effects.
It prevents the virus from binding to any human cells by blocking all receptors.
What is the primary function of the sybo: They bind to non-overlapping epitopes on the RBD to block interaction with the ACE2 receptor.
They bind to overlapping epitopes on the RBD to enhance viral entry.
They bind to the N-terminal domain of the spike protein to prevent viral replication.
They bind to the ACE2 receptor directly to inhibit viral attachment.
Why is the dual targeting strategy of Sb: It engages multiple critical sites on the virus, reducing the chance of escape mutations.
It focuses on a single epitope, making it harder for the virus to mutate.
It targets only the ACE2 receptor, preventing any mutations in the spike protein.
It binds to the viral RNA, inhibiting replication and mutation.
